awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Supporting Faculty Early Career Development in Engineering Education Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite the establishment of engineering education research as a field of inquiry in the last three decades, the social infrastructure available to engineering education researchers is not yet robust enough to consistently support the development of early career faculty across different types of appointments that exist within departments, as faculty in traditional engineering disciplines, or as a part of centers. The purpose of this early-concept project is to explore the development of an engineering education specific community to support early career faculty in engineering education. This project focuses on the National Science Foundation's CAREER award as a particular indicator of early success in engineering education. Using an untested approach to infrastructure development for early engineering education researchers, the project applies theories from organizational change literature in order to equitably provide CAREER application resources and support to early career engineering education researchers throughout the United States.

Using collaborative inquiry, we will build a base of existing CAREER awardees and explore particular advice, resources, and trends that would be important to consider and include in developing an early CAREER mentor network. This first phase will generate engineering education specific (as opposed to general CAREER application advice that many universities provide) resources that can be contributed to a change network. The second, and most intensive phase of this project, focuses on extending the current network to provide these EER specific resources equitable to early career engineering education faculty.

This effort addresses the concerns around differential faculty support within different types of appointments and provides leadership development to support engineering education faculty's movement into core positions with the community. This work provides support and resources for faculty who are often "lone wolves" or otherwise unsupported in engineering education researchers at their institutions. These individuals play an important role in the engineering education research community and equitable access to resources for CAREER application development provides not only strong development for researchers at engineering departments and centers but also to those who connect into more traditional engineering spaces. By expanding who has access to engineering education research resources and support, we can diversify and improve the quality of CAREER applications. Finally, a focus on long-term sustainability will embed the changes made by building this much needed infrastructure to assist engineering education researchers nationwide and create lasting change in engineering education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this research and implementation project was to develop an engineering education specific community to support the development of early career faculty. This project focused on the NSF CAREER award as a particular indicator of early success in engineering education. Engineering Education Research (EER) has developed into a field of expertise and a career pathway over the past three decades. Despite the establishment of EER as a field of inquiry, the social infrastructure available to engineering education researchers was not yet robust enough to consistently support the development of early career faculty across different types of appointments (within EER departments, as faculty in traditional engineering disciplines, or as a part of centers, etc.). To address this need, this project focused on three areas of effort:  1) building a base, 2) extending the network, and 3) sustaining community. In building a base, this project focused on connecting current early and later career NSF CAREER awardees to develop a vibrant community of already recognized scholars. The goal of this part of the grant was to develop mentoring and community among EER researchers. Extending the network involved a series of in-person and online webinars developed and hosted by the CAREER awardee network to provide evidence-based ways to improve the quality and number of EEC CAREER applications submitted. The focus of this phase was on creating wider access to resources and evidence-based advice to develop a stronger EER community. The final phase focused on creating sustainable patterns of mentoring and CAREER award development support by collating resources and developing materials to be shared with the entire community.

 

In the first year of this project, a collaborative inquiry retreat was held with 27 NSF CAREER awardees in engineering education (~42% of all awardees at the time of the event). These participants ranged from established professors in the field to recent awardees. The retreat involved mentoring among participants as well as answering three prompts: 1) What do you wish you had known when applying for an NSF CARER award? 2) What makes a great CAREER proposal? and 3) What resources were helpful to you or need to be created to support NSF CAREER proposals? Additionally, individuals were interviewed about their CAREER proposal experiences. Artifacts, recorded discussions, and interviews were analyzed and a framework for successful proposals emerged, the 5 I?s of being CAREER ready. The Five I?s include: Ideas, Integration, Impact, Identity, and Infrastructure.

 

This retreat led to the development of resources and a workshop for CAREER applicants. The workshop was offered at the 2019 and 2020 American Society for Engineering Education Annual Conference and Exposition. Additionally, we developed a diagnostic tool for CAREER proposal submission readiness that included key questions related to institutional and administrative support for the grant efforts not only in the proposal stage but also in the implementation and management stages. These questions help early career faculty seek out support during the proposal process for maximum success. This framework and resources were also shared at an NSF CAREER webinar and through three workshops with the Purdue College of Engineering. Fifteen workshop participants were also matched with successful CAREER awardees to be mentored in the proposal preparation process.

 

We also found that faculty at institutions that are not Ph.D. granting, designated as high research activity, or in positions associated with tenure-track equivalent had more significant challenges in working with sponsored programs and having support in developing the required documents for submission. Additionally, individuals from these types of institutions also had higher teaching and service responsibilities. Buy-in from department heads for release from these responsibilities varied. All individuals had challenges in managing a sole PI grant once funded. Many of the institutional pieces of grant management were either new to faculty or new in a non-collaborative effort. Additionally, institutional resources to support professional development in grant management were scarce, even at high research institutions. These findings provide ways to support faculty across positions within EER to allow for more equitable engagement with the CAREER program.

 

The results of this work are that eight participants in workshops and an additional three individuals who engaged with materials, to date and our knowledge, have been successful in receiving NSF CAREER awards. These awards are predominately within the Division of Engineering Education and Centers but do span across the Directorate for Engineering. Additionally, resources developed from the collaborative inquiry retreat and existing resources gathered from a survey of engineering education faculty have been placed in an open repository to create opportunities for sustained, high quality CAREER proposal submissions (https://engineering.purdue.edu/STRIDE/research/EAGER%20CAREER).
